repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: A. B. Guthrie Jr. (1901-1991), Montana-born writer whose popular Western novels include The Big Sky (1947), The Way West (1949), and Fair Land, Fair Land (1982). His autobiography was published in 1965. In his later years Guthrie became an outspoken advocate of conservation in the West.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The A. B. Guthrie Jr. Papers were purchased in 1993 from D'Archivists. The A. B. Guthrie Jr. Papers Addition consists of three boxes of material donated by Mrs. A. B. Guthrie Jr. in 1993.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The A. B. Guthrie Jr. Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: A. B. Guthrie Jr. Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 55-56 contain audiovisual material. Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

bioghist.head: A. B. Guthrie Jr. (1901-1991)
bioghist.p: Alfred Bertram ("Bud") Guthrie Jr. was born in Bedford, Indiana, on January 13, 1901. The following June he moved with his family to Choteau, Montana, when his father became principal of the newly created Teton County High School there.

At age fourteen Guthrie began work as a printer's devil for the local newspaper, the Choteau Acantha . He graduated from high school in 1919 and entered the University of Washington to study journalism. After a semester he transferred to the University of Montana because, as he said, "I disliked the climate. Days on end of rain and cloudy skies." While at Montana, he studied under H. G. Merriam, considered the dean of Western journalists, and gained experience by contributing to the regional magazine Frontier.

Upon graduating with honors in 1923, Guthrie went with a friend to Mexico to work on an irrigation project. Soon after Guthrie went to California but failed to locate employment. He returned to Montana in 1924 and found temporary work with the Forest Service, which was conducting a decennial agricultural census. When this job ended, he left Montana to work in an uncle's flour and feed mill in Attica, New York. The mill burned down shortly after Guthrie arrived, leaving him unemployed once again.

In 1926, Guthrie found a position in journalism, working as a reporter on the Lexington Leader in Lexington, Kentucky. His new position and his rapid promotions meant that he felt able to ask his high school sweetheart, Harriet Larson, to marry him. Married in 1931, the couple had two children, Alfred Bertram Guthrie III and Helen Guthrie.

Throughout the 1930s, Guthrie's success as journalist with the Leader increased, but so did his desire to become a serious writer. In 1939 he took a leave of absence to travel to Minnesota with his mother, who was being treated for a terminal illness. While reading many Westerns and detective stories, Guthrie decided to write one himself, later noting that "I was going to write a Western and a mystery but I found out it did not come as easy as I thought it would." The result of this decision was the novel Murders at Moon Dance , published by Dutton in 1943. Although Guthrie later considered it "a trashy piece of work," it did fairly well for a first novel and was also published in England and Argentina.

In 1944 Guthrie received a Nieman Fellowship. During his term at Harvard he met Theodore Morrison, a member of the literature faculty and a former associate editor of the Atlantic Monthly. Under Morrison's tutelage, Guthrie's wrote his first major novel, The Big Sky . Published in 1947 by William Sloane and Associates, it was highly praised and brought him recognition. He immediately began research for a sequel to this popular success, and in 1949 he published The Way West.

The Way West won the Pulitzer Prize in May of 1950. His increasing stature brought him many requests for articles from such magazines as Life , Liberty , Atlantic Monthly , Westways , and the Saturday Evening Post. This income, along with the prize money, allowed Guthrie to retire from journalism and return to Montana.

In 1951 Guthrie was invited to Hollywood to write the screenplay for Jack Schaefer's Shane . After the movie's success, Guthrie went on to write several more scripts. including the Hecht-Hill film The Kentuckian and an adaptation of Bent's Fort that never went to production. His last work in Hollywood was a script based on his own novel These Thousand Hills (1956).

The Big It , Guthrie's first book of short stories, was published in 1960. Guthrie published little in the early 1960s, but his popular autobiography, The Blue Hen's Chick , appeared in 1965. His marriage to Harriet Larson had ended, and Guthrie married Carol Luthin in 1967.

Guthrie now decided to continue his "epic of the West" begun with The Big Sky, producing Arfive, (1970), The Last Valley (1975), and Fair Land, Fair Land (1982). During this period, continuing his early interest in detective Westerns, he wrote a series of books featuring the Western sleuth Chick Charleston (a county sheriff in Montana) and his educated sidekick Jason Beard. The series included Wild Pitch , The Genuine Article , and Playing Catch-up , and won a number of awards, including the Silver Spur Award of the Western Writers Association and an award from the National Cowboy Hall of Fame. Guthrie's last "western entertainment," Murder in the Cotswolds (1989), featured the same characters but was set in the English countryside.

The preservation of the West he loved became a major concern of Guthrie's during his later years. He increasingly accepted public engagements and writing assignments that would allow him to speak out on Western environmental abuses, becoming a "patron saint" for a number of environmental organizations. In 1988 David Petersen edited and published a collection of Guthrie's preservationist writings: Big Sky, Fair Land: The Environmental Essays of A. B. Guthrie Jr.
A. B. Guthrie Jr. died in May 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The A. B. Guthrie Jr. Papers document the life and literary career of A. B. Guthrie Jr., known for his Western novels and environmental writings. The papers span the dates 1901-1991.

The register that follows is based upon the finding aid produced by D'Archivists to accompany the collection. The papers are organized into nine series: I. Correspondence; II. Writings; III. Personal Papers; IV. Subject Files; V. Research Files; VI. Photographs; VII. Printed Material; VIII. Audio and Video Recordings; and XI. A.B. Guthrie Jr. Papers Addition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The family correspondence spans the life of A. B. Guthrie. Letters from his parents contain information on Guthrie's life, particularly on his childhood in Montana, and provide insight into Guthrie's writings. Correspondence with his siblings discusses both personal and professional subjects, including Guthrie's own view of his craft. There are courtship letters between Guthrie and his first wife Harriet, as well as substantial correspondence with their children and with his second wife Carol and their two children.

did.unittitle: Mr. and Mrs. A.B. Guthrie Sr. to A.B. Guthrie Jr.
Charles (Chick) Guthrie to A.B. Guthrie Jr. and family
Charles (Chick) Guthrie to A.B. Guthrie Jr. and family
Jane Haugen family and A.B. Guthrie Jr.
Jane Haugen family and A.B. Guthrie Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The chronological file contains routine correspondence from friends and colleagues, fan mail, requests for speaking engagements and letters concerning personal appearances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Guthrie's correspondence with agents begins in the mid-1940s. Topics include the sales negotiations for essays, articles, and books; criticism of Guthrie's work; career advice; and encouragement to Guthrie after his failure to win the Pulitzer Prize for The Big Sky. Early letters often contain information on the nature of writings by Guthrie no longer extant. Guthrie's earliest agent was Maxwell Aley, but he soon moved to the firm of Brandt & Brandt, while retaining Aley for certain assignments. Information on Guthrie's lecture tours can be found in the Lee Kedick correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publishers Correspondence contains revision suggestions and editorial advice, financial informations, royalty records, and sales statistics. Guthrie's correspondence with William Sloane Associates and Houghton Mifflin is particularly rich in editorial recommendations. While Guthrie batched much of his publisher- related correspondence, he at times separated some files related to particular works. These separated files have been arranged under the individual titles of the works in the Writings series. The "Publishers' Queries" section of this series contains invitiations to Guthrie to write for various publications, and are substantially in their original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings is organized in several sections: Books, Articles, Introductions and Reviews, Speeches, and Other Writings. Guthrie's works are arranged chronologically within each section. Under each title can be found manuscripts, correspondence relating to the work, publicity material, dustjackets, and financial records. This is substantially Guthrie's own order for this material. Other relevant information, however, can often be found in the chronological files of Publishers' correspondence. For example, the William Sloane Associates files for 1947-48 contains correspondence bearing on the evaluation, marketing, distribution and sales of The Big Sky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Descriptions such as "my typed version" are taken from notecards that Guthrie inserted at the beginnings of manuscript files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "The Blue Hen's Chick" is Guthrie's unpublished autobiography. Few of the manuscripts are dated, and Guthrie's original order has been preserved, even though some chapters appear to be out of numerical sequence. It seems likely that these groupings represent various stages of revision. The section titles in quotation marks are taken from notes by Guthrie.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the mid-1950s Guthrie was asked by McGraw-Hill to be the supervising editor of a series of books on the "Great American Trails." These correspondence files document Guthrie's relations with the principal editors at McGraw-Hill and with the authors of the series volumes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: After the success of The Big Sky and The Way West , Guthrie was frequently asked to contribute introductions to books by colleagues and to review both fiction and scholarly works on the American West. The citations in this section are Guthrie's own. Undated manuscripts are followed by dated manuscripts, arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The notes for and drafts of many of Guthrie's speeches are located in this section. Many manuscripts are untitled, as Guthrie sometimes delivered several versions or partial versions of the same talk, or spoke informally from notes. David Peterson drew on the speeches for his compilation of Guthrie's environmental essays, Big Sky, Fair Land (1988). Recordings of some talks are found in Audio and Video Recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section has two parts: Prose and Poetry. Prose consists largely of drafts of material left unpublished at Guthrie's death and unidentified working drafts. The poetry, much of it untitled, is in the original order.

"Five thousand dead...," typescript original. "Original of poem written (but not sent) to Richard Hugo." Inscribed by ABG

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains material relating to Guthrie's finances, medical records, and educational activities. The bank accounts document Guthrie's residences in Kentucky and Montana.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, itineraries, lecture notes on the American West
Newspaper clippings, promotional material and assorted autobiographical musings

A.B. Guthrie Jr., Testimonial Dinner, University of Kentucky. Correspondence, 1950. Correspondents include: Dwight D. Eisenhower, Edward Lasker, Sidney Katz, Governor Earl Clements, Louis Lyons, Grayson L. Kirk, Fletcher Martin, Helen Cruthers, William Rainey, Bernard DeVoto, Joe Howard, Mildred Walker, Lee Keedick, Maxwell Aley, John F. Day, Paul Hughes. Correspondence, Bank statements, lists, and legal papers relating to Mike Kennedy's case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Beginning in 1951, Guthrie journeyed to Hollywood and, for the moment, put his novel writing on hold, to write the screenplay to Shane for George Stevens Productions. The film was released in 1953. He returned to Hollywood from time to time in attempts to write screenplays for The Way West (United Artists, 1967), The Kentuckian (Twentieth Century-Fox, 1955), and a failed attempt at penning These Thousand Hills (Twentieth Century-Fox, 1956). He would also write unproduced pilots for television. The correspondence (frequently detailed) deals with these productions as well as with explorations into various consulting assignments and motion picture projects.

did.unittitle: General Correspondence. Correspondents include: Ed Lasker (RKO Radio Pictures), Frank P. Rosenberg (20th Century-Fox), Ivan Moffat (producer, George Stevens Productions), Monte Brice (producer, Paramount Pictures), Ned Brown (MCA Agency), Jerry Wald (Vice President, Columbia Pictures), Jean Hersholt, Arthur Kramer (story editor, 20th Century-Fox), Julian Blaustein (independent producer), David Weisbart, (producer, 20th Century-Fox), William Rowland (Paramount Pictures), and A.B. Guthrie Jr. Re: contract negotiations, screen credit arbitration, story ideas, consulting opportunities, and script revisions for Shane , The Big Sky , These Thousand Hills , The Kentuckian , and The Way West .

General Correspondence. Correspondents include: Monte Brice, Jerry Bresler (Columbia Pictures), Burt Lancaster, David Weisbart, William Rowland, Hal Kanter (20th Century-Fox), Ben Benjamin, James R. Webb (screenwriter), Philip Miller (Ashley Famous Agency), Harold Hecht (producer, Harold Hecht Company), Budd Schulberg (producer), and A.B. Guthrie Jr. Re: story ideas, script revisions, consulting opportunities and The Way West , also television project "Sun Prairie."

Ben Benjamin/Famous Artists Agency. Correspondence. Re: extensive detail relative to Guthrie's credited and uncredited/unproduced screenwriting, contract negotiations, and employment opportunities in motion pictures and television.

Hecht, Hill and Lancaster Productions. Correspondence. Correspondents include: company principals James Hill, Harold Hecht, and Burt Lancaster; Fred Zinnemann (director), Irving Ravetch (screenwriter). Re: detailed negotiations and progress in writing of The Way West and The Kentuckian , and speculative projects in motion pictures and television.

Tom Gries. Correspondence. Motion picture director and writer who corresponded with A.B. Guthrie Jr. about details in filming Guthrie's Arfive and "Sun Prairie." Also discusses Gries' own The Hawaiians .
The Big Sky . Reviews, newspaper clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Guthrie was accepted as a Nieman Fellow in 1944. During his time at Harvard University, he began work on The Big Sky , published three years later.

did.unittitle: Correspondence. To A.B. Guthrie Jr. from "Sunny" regarding Sunny's experience as a Nieman Fellow

A.B. Guthrie Jr. Application. Written proposal, and signed letters of recommendation from Judge Max Swinford, Struthers Burt, Edward Weeks, Governor Willis, Dr. Henry H. Hill, and Dr. Charles D. Cawood, Virginius Dabney, Thomas Clark, Paul Hughes, and John F. Day.
Correspondence. Correspondents primarily include Louis Lyons and James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, with correspondence from A.B. Guthrie Jr. Also Nieman conference programs.
Coursework, 1944. Includes Harvard University catalog, class outlines, research pamphlets and guides for coursework, holograph class notes by A.B. Guthrie Jr.
Programs, publicity, memorabilia. Bread Loaf conference bulletins, programs, publicity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Guthrie's organized file card system reflecting research bibliography and cross-referencing for research on The Big Sky and The Way West .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photographs series contains portraits of Guthrie at various stages of his life, including pictures of him as a child, at book signings, and with colleagues at conferences; family photographs, including pictures of his first wife Harriet Larson and other relatives; and photos of his 1950 trip down the Missouri River with Bernard DeVoto and William J. Lederer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of issues of publications containing articles by A. B. Guthrie Jr. A few of these periodicals also contain feature or sidebar articles on Guthrie. The magazines have been arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These recordings document Guthrie's speaking style from the late 1940s until 1990 and include tapes of radio broadcasts, interviews, readings, and speeches. In addition, there are 15 discs of the testimonial dinner held for Guthrie at the University of Kentucky after he won the Pulitzer Prize; they feature tributes to Guthrie by friends, students and colleagues, many of whom are also represented in the correspondence. These materials are housed in the Historical Sound Recordings Department of Sterling Memorial Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual material. Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 15 12-inch metal based Audiodisc Custom Recordings, numbered sides 1-30. Testimonial dinner for A.B. Guthrie Jr., 19 May 1950, at the University of Kentucky. Dan Bowmar, master of ceremonies, long-time co-worker at the Lexington Leader and friend of ABG; Harmon Lee Donovan, president of the University of Kentucky; Dr. Theodore Morrison, Harvard University, ABG's mentor while writing The Big Sky; William J. Lederer, novelist who journeyed the length of the Missouri River with ABG; English 117 skit satarizing Guthrie's character from The Big Sky and The Way West and written and acted by ABG's students; Clay Stuart, of the Speakeasy Club founded by ABG; and A.B. Guthrie Jr. See also 1 C-60 audio cassette recordings of same entitled "A.B. Guthrie Recordings 1, 2 and 3."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1 12-inch metal based Audiodisc Custom Recording, "Jay Jay--A.B. Guthrie Show, Side #1 & 2." ca. May 1953. A biographical tribute broadcast on Lexington, Kentucky's WBLK readio on Guthrie's departure from Kentucky to Montana. See also 1 C-60 audio cassette recording of same entitled "A.B. Guthrie Recordings, 3."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1 12-inch metal based Audiodisc Custom Recording, "For ABG, Jr.--start inside, 7 May 1953." Radio broadcast on WBLK, Lexington, Kentucky. ABG is interviewed about motion pictures The Big Sky and Shane. Also discusses literary adaptations to film, impending departure for Hollywood to write a screenplay from Felix Holt's Gabriel Horn, released as The Kentuckian (1955). Also discusses teaching of writing to students, getting stories published, challenges in working with a literary agent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1 7-inch Federal Perma Disc customized recording. "Bud on Snakes." One side only, n.d. Speech given at the Speakeasy Club, Lexington, Kentucky.

did.unittitle: "A.B. Guthrie Recordings 1," made from audiodiscs. Includes: a) radio interview broadcast on WBLK, Lexington, Kentucky, 7 May 1953; b) four of the speeches given at a testimonial dinner for A.B. Guthrie Jr., 19 May 1950, at the University of Kentucky. Speakers include Dan Bowmar, Harmon Lee Donovan, Theodore Morrison, and William J. Lederer (audiocassette)

"A.B. Guthrie Recordings 2," made from audiodiscs. Includes remainder of testimonial dinner speeches: a) William J. Lederer (concluded); b) English 117 skit satarizing Guthrie's character from The Big Sky and The Way West and written and acted by ABG's students; c) Arthur Lloyd; d) Ed Templin; e) Clay Stuart, of the Speakeasy Club (audiocassette)

"A.B. Guthrie Recordings 3," made from audiodiscs. Includes: a) A.B. Guthrie Jr. speech from testimonial dinner; b) "Jay Jay--A.B. Guthrie Show, Side #1 & 2." ca. May 1953 (a biographical tribute broadcast on Lexington, Kentucky's WBLK radio on Guthrie's departure from Kentucky to Montana); c) "Bud on Snakes," speech given at the Speakeasy Club, Lexington, Kentucky (audiocassette)

A. B. Guthrie Jr. Papers Addition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The A. B. Guthrie Jr. Papers Addition consists of three boxes of material acquired from Mrs. A. B. Guthrie Jr. in 1993. The papers include four folders of correspondence, with additional reviews, subject files, and printed material. The material was arranged in a similar order of the A. B. Guthrie Jr. Papers in series above.
